message_1: Let P be the proposition "Today is Monday" and Q be the proposition "It is raining outside." If we know that P is true, and Q is false, what is the truth value of the proposition "Today is Monday and it is raining outside"?
message_2:
To determine the truth value of the proposition "Today is Monday and it is raining outside," we need to look at the conjunction of P and Q, which is represented as P ∧ Q. 

In this case, we know that P is true (Today is Monday) and Q is false (It is not raining outside). The conjunction P ∧ Q is true only if both P and Q are true. Since Q is false, the conjunction P ∧ Q is also false.

So, the truth value of the proposition "Today is Monday and it is raining outside" is false.
